Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: They prepare a sermon for Sunday service to guide the congregation in moral decisions.
Story: I was halfway through outlining my sermon for Sunday, the kind that needed careful thought and prayer, when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, my old college friend. “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m drowning in screws and planks over here. These instructions make no sense.” I glanced at the clock—just two hours left before I needed to send my sermon draft to the church secretary. My mind raced. As a friend, I wanted to be there for Mark, especially since he’d just moved and didn’t know many people in town. He’d helped me through rough patches before; I owed him. But as a pastor, I felt the weight of responsibility to my congregation, to offer them guidance and clarity on Sunday. I could hear the urgency in Mark’s voice, but I also felt the pressure of unfinished work and the expectations of my role. My heart tugged in two directions, and I sat there, phone in hand, torn between the friend who needed me now and the congregation counting on me later.
